AmeriGas has a bulkhead piping system which is used for loading trucks and unloading
railcars. They use hoses as an extension of the piping to do the transfer. 

The Alternate case is using stating the hose in the scenario because the hose is an extension of the bulkhead. The active mitigation devices were assumed to work as designed, limiting the release to the contents of the hose. Using RMP Comp the calculated distance to 1 psi overpressure end point for vapor cloud explosion is 0.09 miles.

Pumps and Compressors were also considered. Maintenance and mitigation devices are in
place that would mitigate the risks of release from pumps and compressors. Vessel
overfilling is mitigated administratively. The storage tanks are filled only to a maximum of
85 % of the total capacity to allow expansion of the product.

Emergency Response Plan
The facility maintains an Emergency Action Plan (EAP). The plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire, law enforcement and medical organizations. 
Notification of potentially affected neighbors would be coordinated through the fire department or law enforcement after consultation with site personnel. If an actual incident occurs, the plan gives guidance to employees on how to respond if it is a minor problem and easily controlled on site. Larger emergencies require assistance from the local emergency response organizations and employees are knowledgeable as to when that outside assistance is required. 

The plans are reviewed periodically to ensure that they remain up-to-date, reflecting current activities on site and employees are trained on their responsibilities in an emergency to ensure prompt response.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
The facility has no plans at the present time to make any changes.

Offsite Consequence Analysis Results

Worst Case Scenario 
A catastrophic rupture of above ground propane tank resulting in total loss of contents
of one of the tanks was considered as the worst-­‐case scenario. The total quantity
released was 108,120 lbs. The propane was assumed to disperse in the flammable
range, encounter areas of sufficient congestion and confinement and result in a vapor
cloud explosion.
RMP Comp was used as a tool to calculate distance to endpoints of 1 psi overpressure: 0.4 miles
(0.6 Kilometers). This is the distance to the overpressure endpoint of 1 pound per square inch
specified for this regulated substance under the RMP Rule.
RMP assumes meteorological conditions for the worst-­‐case scenario of atmospheric
stability class F (stable atmosphere) and wind speed 1.5 meters per second (3.4 miles
per hour). Ambient air temperature assumed is 25° C (77 ° F).
Per RMP Comp, the calculated distance to 1 psi overpressure end point for vapor cloud
explosion is 0.40 miles. An overpressure of 1 psi may cause damage and/or injuries to
public & environmental receptors (receptors shown below in chart). Per CalARP 2750,
other flammable end point criteria such as radiant heat of 5kw/m2 for 40 seconds and
lower flammability limit was considered but is not expected to produce end point worse
than vapor cloud explosion discussed.

Assumption
RMP assumes meteorological conditions for the worst-­case scenario of atmospheric stability
class F (stable atmosphere) and wind speed 1.5 meters per second (3.4 miles per hour). Ambient
air temperature assumed is 25 deg C (77 deg F).

Alternative Release Scenario
For alternative release scenario, release from transfer hoses at the facility was chosen.
Broken or burst propane loading hoses were determined to be the most common failure.

Facility Description
The AmeriGas Atwater terminal is propane storage and distribution facility.  The process involves unloading propane from rail cars into the propane bulk storage tanks and loading propane into transports using a Compressor.
The facility includes three (3) above-ground storage tanks with capacity of 30,000 gallons each. It has one (1) Compressor used to unload the rails cars.  The terminal has a siding with one rail tower designed to hook to rail cars and unload propane to storage tanks using the Compressor. The Compressor withdraws propane vapors from the storage tank and compresses them or increase their pressure and discharge into the rail cars to be unloaded. This process slightly decreases the pressure in the bulk storage tanks and increases the pressure in the rail cars. As a result, liquid propane flows from rail car to the bulk storage tanks.
There is one bulkhead for loading transports. When transport arrives, the Compressor is used to load product from storage tanks into the transports.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy 
The same properties that make propane valuable as a fuel also make it necessary to practice certain safety precautions in handling it to prevent leaks, spills and accidents. First and foremost, in our operations, efforts are undertaken to ensure employee and contractor safety while on site as well as to minimize the risk of exposure to the surrounding communities. It is our company policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state and local rules and regulations. The Facility has Logistics Manager and a Terminal Operations Supervisor who are able to immediately respond to a serious incident and provide technical expertise to emergency response agencies as needed at the scene of the incident. AmeriGas also maintains an around the clock Emergency Communications Center (ECC), which handles all after-hours and emergency calls from around the country.
